content.description: A decent up problem that starts where the traverse does, just left of the third crack system. It climbs bomber holds up to a crappy top-out. It's best just to jump off or downclimb. A good way to warm up for the other routes on the wall.
content.location: Start just left of the left-most crack on the wall.

content.description: This problem climbs the South East arete of the Big Betty Boulder.  The feet are a little thin at the beginning.

The Rotund is a left-to-right traverse that begins in a crack, sidepull feature, trends higher in the middle, drops down, and finishes on some funky, right-facing, juggy holds. The movement on this route is varied and interesting, the holds range from slopey, frictiony sidepulls to cool fingerjugs. There isn't any one crux, just a series of V2-V3 moves that culminate in a great pump.
content.location:
The Rotund is on the fourth major formation (from north to south) at Biglandia. I find the best approach is to hike in on the west side of the ridge on an old road and then cut up and left to a lowpoint in the ridge that allows passage to the other side. From this obvious passable lowpoint, The Rotund is on the first major boulder to the north.

It gets morning sun and afternoon shade.

content.description: Sky Pilot is easier down low then builds to a difficult move up high. Start low as you want on good holds.
content.protection: A pad or 2 might be a good idea.
content.location:
On the far left side of the same wall as "

The Bitch Slap

", climb the lichen free highball up one of the highest parts of the wall.

content.description: This is a long right to left traverse starting in a corner and finishing at the end of the wall. It is very sharp in sections. The finish is a great problem in itself.
content.protection: You might want to tape some tips to curtail the shredding.
content.location:
It lies about 65 to 70 yards left (south) of

The Rotund

and Abdo Cave. Look for a long, pocketed wall with a corner on the right hand side.

content.description: A right to left traverse that is kinda cruxy dropping down onto the triangular juggy thing near the start and then a bit of endurance is helpful. Traverse left until you can traverse no more. Not as good as the other traverses here but worth doing. Maybe not quite as hard as V7 but whatever....
content.location: This problem is located on the Redneck Wall which is the first major wall encountered when hiking on the east side of the ridge from the road. It is tall, probably 20+ feet, and three cracks split the middle of the face. The traverse starts just left of the left-most crack.

content.description: This problem is a sit start with some large moves through good holds.
content.location:
It is found on the same wall as

The Rotund

. Start sitting low with the right hand on a crimp and work up through a sidepull and a small crimp to bigger holds to top out.

content.description: From pockets move up into a right hand undercling below the small roof, make the reach to the ledge and get yourself up and over. Short, easy, and fun.
content.location: South face of the Big Betty Boulder.

content.description: This problem is on the Big Betty Boulder, which is the lone large boulder that sits below the ridge line in the Biglandia area.  On the less than vertical slabby east face, start from a pocket and a side pull and high-step your way straight up.
If you stay low for the entire length of the traverse, the grade is V7, and there are two distinct cruxes that are crimpy and have a shallow pocket or two. Then it's all about endurance.
content.protection: One or two pads add comfort at difficult spots. Landing is near perfect though and you're never more than a foot off the ground.
content.location: After crossing through the ridge, angle down and right (southeast?) toward the house. You'll see a barbed wire fence, follow this back up to the ridge, and it will deposit you right at the beginning of the traverse. Apparently the land left of the fence is private.

content.description: Traverse all the way around the Betty Boulder.
content.protection: A pad could help for some sections.
